Award.AwardTitle: Ascidian Transferrins and the Evolution of Metal Trafficking
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program, co-funded with the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences (MCB), supports work by Professor Ann Valentine at Yale University to carry out fundamental studies on transferrin proteins from the ascidian Ciona intestinalis. Transferrin proteins manage iron, which is vital for most life forms, yet is toxic under many conditions. Iron is particularly difficult for organisms to control in environments that contain oxygen because it tends to form insoluble iron oxides (e.g., rust). Ascidians sequester remarkable concentrations of metal ions from seawater, and thus may offer valuable lessons in metal ion management. They fall on the evolutionary boundary between invertebrates and vertebrates. Ascidians have two different transferrin proteins, related to (but very different from) the ones found in vertebrates, which may work together to manage iron and other metal ions. This work will probe the structure and function of these two ascidian transferrin proteins, as well as the interactions between them.

Taken together, these studies will offer lessons about how the capacity evolved to manage very insoluble metal ions in an aerobic environment, and will provide clues to the trafficking of iron and other metals. This inquiry sits at the intersection of inorganic and bioinorganic chemistry, biogeochemistry (including trace element cycling in the environment), developmental biology, and organism and protein evolution. Research activities will be integrated with chemistry outreach and with the continued development of an introductory chemistry course for freshman with less-than-average preparation who may nonetheless be interested in university majors in the sciences and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The set of metals necessary for life on Earth includes some that are problematic. Life evolved to depend on iron because iron does the chemistry that biology wants (transfers electrons in just the right way, carries oxygen reversibly, etc.) and is sufficiently abundant and bioavailable that organisms can subsist using iron. But the accumulation of oxygen in our atmosphere billions of years ago brought several problems with iron. Of iron’s common oxidation states, the iron 2+ state is toxic because it reacts with oxygen to form reactive oxygen species including free radicals, and the 3+ state is insoluble and forms rust. In the latter reaction, water molecules bound to the metal ion lose protons (a process called hydrolysis) and the resulting oxide species precipitate out of solution. Organisms have evolved ways to sequester, protect, and move iron, but there are still many problems with iron deficiency and iron overload. Hosts and infecting organisms also fight for iron in a bioinorganic arms race. Besides iron, other hydrolysis-prone metal ions have more limited roles (like vanadium) or still-controversial roles (like titanium). One of the ways that higher organisms manage iron is with a protein called transferrin. The transferrin in human blood serum binds many other metal ions besides iron.

 

One group of organisms that are expert at the management of hydrolysis-prone metals is the ascidians (also called “sea squirts”) (Figure 1). Ascidians, on the evolutionary boundary between invertebrates and vertebrates, have been known for over 100 years to sequester remarkably high concentrations of very hydrolysis-prone metals from the seawater they filter. They offer valuable lessons in metal ion management, having minimalist versions of the metal trafficking machinery of higher organisms. These darlings of developmental biology are also “canaries in the coal mine” for metal pollution in coastal waters. The ascidian genome features genes for two very novel transferrin proteins related to (but different from) the ones found in vertebrates. These proteins may work together to manage iron and other metal ions. This award has supported fundamental studies on the transferrin proteins from the ascidian Ciona intestinalis. This work has probed the structure and function of these two ascidian transferrin proteins, as well as the interactions between them. A few of the important outcomes of the work are the discovery that the ascidian monolobal transferrin (Figure 2) binds iron in a very different way than does the well-studied human serum transferrin. Advanced Electron Paramagnetic Resonance techniques characterized the environment of the iron. Unlike the human protein, nicatransferrin catalyzes the reduction of iron from the 3+ state to the 2+ state. This surprising finding points towards a primitive metal trafficking scheme quite different from the one in vertebrates.

 

Taken together, these studies offer lessons about how the capacity evolved to manage very insoluble metal ions in an aerobic environment, and provide clues to the trafficking of iron and other metals. This inquiry sits at the intersection of inorganic and bioinorganic chemistry, biogeochemistry (including trace element cycling in the environment), developmental biology, and organism and protein evolution.

 

In addition, this award supported a research program that educated and trained undergraduates, grad students, and postdocs at the interface of inorganic chemistry and biochemistry. Research activities were integrated with chemistry outreach and with the development of an introductory course for less-prepared freshmen who are interested in science majors.
